allAnswers: Not a Cause for a Cause

questions.question: "You're either with us or against us."
questions.explanation: This is a False Dilemma because it presents only two options when there may be more alternatives or nuances to consider. It oversimplifies a complex situation into an 'either/or' choice.

questions.question: "If you don't vote for this bill, you don't care about education."
questions.explanation: This is a False Dilemma because it falsely limits the choices to voting for the bill or not caring about education, ignoring other possible positions.

questions.question: "Either we ban all immigration or we have no control over our borders."
questions.explanation: This is a False Dilemma because it suggests only two extreme options, ignoring the possibility of controlled or regulated immigration.

questions.question: "You either love the new policy or you hate progress."
questions.explanation: This is a False Dilemma because it presents only two extreme views, ignoring the possibility of nuanced opinions on the new policy and progress.

questions.question: "If we don’t cut down on welfare spending, the economy will collapse."
questions.explanation: This is a False Dilemma because it presents only two options, ignoring other potential economic solutions that don't involve cutting welfare spending.

questions.question: "The rooster crowed, then the sun rose. Therefore, the rooster caused the sun to rise."
questions.ca: Not a Cause for a Cause

questions.question: "I wore my lucky socks, and we won the game. My socks must have caused the win."
questions.ca: Not a Cause for a Cause

questions.question: "I didn't take vitamin C, and then I caught a cold. Lack of vitamin C caused my cold."
questions.ca: Not a Cause for a Cause

questions.question: "I forgot to water my plant, and then it rained. My forgetfulness caused the rain."
questions.ca: Not a Cause for a Cause

questions.question: "The stock market went up after the new president took office, so the new president caused the rise."
questions.ca: Not a Cause for a Cause

questions.question: "If you don't support this policy, you'll be putting your family in danger."
"Vote for this candidate, or our country will be overrun by criminals."
"If we don’t increase the military budget, our enemies will attack us."
"If you don't buy this insurance, you could face financial ruin."
"If you don’t comply with our demands, your business will be ruined."
"My friend got a speeding ticket in that town; all cops there must be corrupt."
"I met two rude people from that city; everyone there must be rude."
"The first two customers were unhappy, so this product must be terrible."
"I saw a teenager vandalizing property; all teenagers must be delinquents."
"Three people I know who eat gluten-free are sickly, so gluten-free diets are unhealthy."
"No one has proven that aliens don’t exist, so they must be real."
"There's no evidence that the new drug is unsafe, so it must be safe."
"You can't prove ghosts aren't real, so they must exist."
"No one can disprove my claim, so it must be true."
"Since scientists haven’t found life on Mars, it must be lifeless."
"No true American would criticize the government."
"No true fan would ever miss a game."
"No true environmentalist would drive a gas-guzzling car."
"No true Christian would commit such a sin."
"No true artist would sell their work commercially."
"The idea came from a convicted felon, so it must be worthless."
"You can't trust that study; it was funded by a corporation."
"He’s from a poor background, so his argument must be flawed."
"That theory was proposed by someone from the 19th century, so it can't be accurate."
"The advice came from a politician, so it must be dishonest."
"You’re friends with someone who cheated on their exam, so you must be a cheater too."
"That activist is supported by a controversial group, so their cause must be bad."
"You work for a company that once had a scandal, so you must be unethical."
"He attended a meeting with extremists, so he must share their beliefs."
"She’s friends with people who often lie, so she must be a liar."
"If it’s raining, the ground is wet. The ground is wet, so it must be raining."
"If I have the flu, I have a fever. I have a fever, so I must have the flu."
"If she’s a good singer, she’ll win the competition. She won, so she must be a good singer."
"If the car is out of gas, it won’t start. The car won’t start, so it must be out of gas."
"If he’s a fast runner, he’ll win the race. He won the race, so he must be a fast runner."
"You say I shouldn't eat junk food, but I’ve seen you eat it too."
"How can you tell me to be punctual when you're always late?"
"You advise me to save money, but you spend extravagantly."
"You criticize my driving, but I’ve seen you make mistakes too."
"How can you tell me to be honest when you’ve lied before?"
"If we allow this, it will lead to a cascade of negative events."
"If we legalize marijuana, soon all drugs will be legal."
"If we permit this behavior, society will collapse."
"If we start censoring speech, it will end in complete government control."
"If we allow same-sex marriage, it will lead to people marrying animals."
"Everyone is switching to this new phone; you should too."
"Most people believe in this superstition, so it must be true."
"You should wear these clothes; everyone is wearing them."
"Join our club; all your friends are members."
"You should vote for this candidate; they’re leading in the polls."
"Don't listen to his argument; he’s not even educated."
"She’s a known liar, so her opinion doesn’t matter."
"He's been in jail, so his views on justice are worthless."
"You can't trust his advice; he’s always been a failure."
"Her argument is invalid because she’s a hypocrite."
"The Bible is true because it says so in the Bible."
"I’m right because I say I’m right."
"This policy is the best because it’s better than the alternatives."
"She’s the best candidate because no one else is as good."
"He’s trustworthy because he’s never lied."
"The team is excellent, so each member must be excellent."
"This cake is delicious, so each ingredient must be delicious."
"The committee made a wise decision, so each member is wise."
"The company is profitable, so each employee must be productive."
"The car is fast, so every part of it must be fast."
"He says we should improve education; he must want to throw more money at a broken system."
"She thinks we should reduce military spending; she must want to leave us defenseless."
"You say you’re for environmental regulations, so you must want to shut down all industries."
"He wants to increase taxes; he must hate hardworking people."
"You support gun control, so you want to take away all our guns."
"A feather is light. What is light cannot be dark. Therefore, a feather cannot be dark."
"I have the right to speak, so what I say must be right."
"The sign said 'fine for parking here,' so I thought it was fine to park."
"All trees have bark. Every dog barks. Therefore, every dog is a tree."
"He’s a good person because he’s good at his job."
"We can't accept that the Earth revolves around the sun because it would mean our ancestors were wrong."
"Believing in evolution makes people think life has no meaning, so it can't be true."
"Accepting climate change would hurt the economy, so it must be false."
"If we don't believe in a just world, we would be depressed, so the world must be just."
"If we admit this law is unjust, it would mean our leaders are wrong, so it must be just."
"This diet must work because a celebrity endorses it."
"This medication is the best because my favorite doctor recommended it."
"This product is superior because a well-known expert says so."
"You should believe in this theory because a Nobel Prize winner supports it."
"This brand is the best because a famous athlete uses it."
